Comment.value:
Portal that will teleport players to a destination chosen from a conversation presented by the portal when you click on it.

Place one of these in your module then from the Advanced tab in its properties click on the Variables button and set the following:

Variable Name          Type          Value
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
DestinationCount         int             The number of destinations.
Destination1                string         Description@WaypointTag
Destination2                string         Description@WaypointTag
...
Destination10               string        Description@WaypointTag


The value for each of the DestinationX variables is made up of 2 parts, the destination description and the tag of a waypoint or object that the player will be sent to. These are separated by the @ character. So, for example, if you want the text in the portal's conversation to say The Castle  and there is a waypoint in the castle with the tag WP_CASTLE, you would set the value of one of the 10 destination variables to
"The Castle@WP_CASTLE".
This will make the portal show "The Castle" as one of the destinations in the list presented in the conversation and when the player clicks that destination, they will be teleported to the waypoint WP_CASTLE.

There are a maximum of 10 destinations possible but not all of them must be used. The DestinationCount variable should be set to the number of destinations that will be presented by the portal during the conversation. Then there should be the same number of DestinationX variables set up. If you only have 5 destinations they must be #s 1 thru 5. Setting the DestinationCount to 11 and adding a variable called Destination11 will not work. See the addendum that came with the Port-Me NPC package (v1.1 and later) to learn how to add more if desired.

If the waypoint for a particular destination variable cannot be found, the portal will NOT present that destination in the conversation.

The WaypointTag portion of the DestinationX variable's value need not be the tag of a waypoint. It can refer to any object except an item, area, or the module.

This is the default waypoint you may place to set a patrol path for a creature or NPC.
1. Create the creature and either use its current Tag or fill in a new one.
2. Place or make sure the WalkWayPoints() is within the body of the On Spawn script for the creature.
3. Place a series of waypoints along the route you wish the creature to walk.
4. Select all of the newly created waypoints and right click. Choose the Create Set option.
5. The waypoint set will have a set name of "WP_" + NPC Tag. Thus if an NPC with the Tag "Guard" will have a waypoint set called "WP_Guard". Note that Tags are case sensitive.

This is the default waypoint you may place to set a patrol path for a creature or NPC.
1. Create the creature and either use its current Tag or fill in a new one.
2. Place or make sure the WalkWayPoints() is within the body of the On Spawn script for the creature.
3. Place a series of waypoints along the route you wish the creature to walk.
4. Select all of the newly created waypoints and right click. Choose the Create Set option.
5. The waypoint set will have a set name of "WP_" + NPC Tag. Thus if an NPC with the Tag "Guard" will have a waypoint set called "WP_Guard". Note that Tags are case sensitive.
On the Advanced tab, replace <Place text here> with whatever information you wish to appear on the Map of an area.
